description: Borrowed from Middle French expression, from Late Latin expressiō, expressiōnem (“a pressing out”).

entries.meaning: The action of expressing thoughts, ideas, feelings, etc.
A particular way of phrasing an idea.

examples: The expression "break a leg!" should not be taken literally.

entries.meaning: A facial appearance usually associated with an emotion.
examples: They stared at the newcomer with a puzzled expression.
The best poker players can tell if the opponents have a good hand by looking at their expression.
Her expression changed from joy to misery after realising her winning lottery ticket had expired.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) An arrangement of symbols denoting values, operations performed on them, and grouping symbols.
(biology) The process of translating a gene into a protein.
(programming) A piece of code in a high-level language that returns a value.
(biology) (manufacturing) The act of pressing or squeezing out.
examples: Breast milk expression can be achieved by hand or with a pump.
However the mechanical expression of juice led to an improvement of the solutes extraction from mash.

entries.meaning: (music) The tone of voice or sound in music.
(mostly preceded by with) emotional involvement or engagement in a text read aloud rendered by the voice of the reciter or the reader
examples: I cannot say that all read with expression. Indeed , this power is hardly to be expected in young children . And though “ to read with expression ...
